newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: Time to bottom fish for Singapore stocks - Vickers.
newsitem.headline: Time to bottom fish for Singapore stocks - Vickers.

text.p: April's sell down of blue chips in Singapore has opened an opportunity for investors to bottom fish, Vickers Ballas Investment Research said on Wednesday.
The Singapore stock market was now undervalued after weak investor sentiment pushed stock prices down over the past three months, the research house said in its monthly research report.
Singapore is trading at a price earning (PE) ratio of 15 times, representing the low-end of its historic PE range of 14 to 24 times. Fair valuation of the market was pegged around PE 19-20 times.
Vickers said it expected the market to bottom out over the next two months given the low valuation and improving fundamentals.
It said recent portfolio adjustments ahead of the revised Morgan Stanley Capital International (MSCI) Singapore Free Index weightings on June 1, 1997, would have been completed.
"We expect the foreign tranches of bank stocks to respond positively."
Singapore's budget announcement expected in late June was also expected to reveal a few goodies, including a good dose of pro-business measures, Vickers said.
The stocks recommended were Cycle & Carriage, Keppel Corporation, Foreign tranches of banks like OCBC and OUB.
Others included stocks with potential growth like Elec & Eltek, MMI Holdings, Sin Soon Huat, Lindeteves-Jacoberg as well as stocks with recovery plays like Haw Par, ST Aerospace and Straits Trading.
Vickers said its recommendation was for investors with a time horizon of about 12 months. The stocks were expected to have an upside of at least 20 percent within that period, it said.
